column4: Hi, I have a file with a permission ----rwx--- (070), i.e: rwx for group and nothing for others. However, I am unable to read it, despite the file's GID and my GID being  the same. Why is this ? There are no ACLs in action too !
paste the output of « ls -ld FILE » and « whoami »
ls -ld gives : "----rwx--- 1 faxer faxer 0 Nov  7 03:48 test.txt"
you have explicitly said the faxer user cannot read, therefore he cannot read
but - he belongs to the 'faxer' group
who owns the file. Shouldn't the group permissions be checked if the user permissions fail
no, you could for example give everyone read and then use group permissions to take away read permissions from a certain group
so what you're saying is that the group flags are not even checked if the user permission check fails ?
basically, you can think of it as the more specific rule applies
but say for example a guest user, who also belongs to the faxer group tries to access the file
sure, he can access the file
in his case, the user flags would still fail, but the group flags would still be checked
the user flag applies to the owner of the file; he is not the owner
